sub_topic: Prove that every group of order 9 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C9 or the non-abelian group of order 9.
message_1: Consider a group G of order 9. Determine whether G is isomorphic to the cyclic group C9 or the non-abelian group of order 9, and provide a detailed explanation of your answer.
message_2:
Since G has order 9, by the Sylow theorems, we know that the number of Sylow 3-subgroups in G must divide 9 and be congruent to 1 modulo 3. This means that there can only be one Sylow 3-subgroup in G, which we will denote as P. Since there is only one such subgroup, it must be normal in G.

Now, let's consider the possible structures of P. Since P is a group of order 9, it must be either cyclic (isomorphic to C9) or non-abelian. However, we know that all groups of prime order p (in this case, p=3^2) are abelian, as they are isomorphic to the cyclic group of order p. Therefore, P must be abelian and isomorphic to C9.

Since P is normal in G and has the same order as G, we can conclude that P = G. Therefore, G is isomorphic to the cyclic group C9. There is no non-abelian group of order 9, as we have shown that any group of order 9 must be abelian and isomorphic to C9.
